questions.question: What is the biggest mistake new technical hires at VC funds make?

options.text: Trying to build everything at once - spreading resources too thin
Focusing too much on one tool

questions.explanation: The biggest mistake new technical hires at VC funds make is trying to build everything at once. They see the full landscape of what's possible and want to implement a comprehensive tech stack from day one. This spreads resources too thin and delivers less value than focusing on fewer things done well.

questions.question: What are the three phases for sequencing your tech stack implementation?

options.text: Learn what your fund needs, build the backbone and quick wins, decide on your big swing

questions.explanation: There are three phases: Phase 1 - Learn what your fund actually needs, Phase 2 - Build the backbone and quick wins, Phase 3 - Decide on your big swing. Don't skip phases.

questions.section: Phase 1: Learn What Your Fund Needs First
questions.question: What should you do before building anything significant?

options.text: Spend time understanding your fund - observation comes before building

questions.explanation: Before you build anything significant, spend time understanding your fund. Observation comes before building. Talk to the people doing the work, understand the thesis and strategy, identify the actual pain points. Don't assume - just because EQT built Motherbrain or Inflection built Kepler doesn't mean your fund needs the same thing.

questions.section: Phase 2: Build the Backbone and Quick Wins
questions.question: What are the two parallel tracks in Phase 2?

options.text: The backbone (foundational infrastructure) and quick wins (small tools that prove value)

questions.explanation: Once you understand your fund, start with two parallel tracks: the backbone (foundational infrastructure everyone needs) and quick wins (small tools that solve specific pain points and prove your value to the team).

questions.section: Phase 2: Build the Backbone and Quick Wins
questions.question: What are the backbone tools that every fund needs?

options.text: CRM and fund operations - don't build these, buy them

questions.explanation: The backbone: CRM and fund operations. These are non-negotiable infrastructure. Every fund needs to track deal flow and manage fund operations. Don't build these. Buy them. Get CRM set up immediately and make sure your team actually uses it.

questions.section: Phase 2: Build the Backbone and Quick Wins
questions.question: What are quick wins?

options.text: Small tools that solve specific pain points, take days or weeks (not months), and prove your value
Tools that take years to build

questions.explanation: Quick wins are small tools that solve specific pain points and prove your value to the team. Examples: a simple dashboard showing portfolio company metrics, automating a painful manual process, a lightweight research workflow improvement. Quick wins should take days or weeks, not months. They should solve real problems people have right now.

questions.section: Phase 3: Decide on Your Big Swing
questions.question: What should you align on before committing to your big project?

options.text: What data you'll need and ensure you have proper funding for both the data and the build

questions.explanation: Before committing to your big project, align with fund leadership on what data you'll need and ensure you have proper funding for both the data and the build. Data subscriptions are expensive. PitchBook costs tens of thousands per year. Harmonic and Specter are significant investments. Have this conversation before you start.

questions.section: Phase 3: Decide on Your Big Swing
questions.question: What is your 'big swing'?

options.text: One big project where you differentiate - maybe a research platform, sourcing infrastructure, or portfolio support tools

questions.explanation: After you've built the backbone and delivered quick wins, you've earned the credibility and understanding to take on one big project. This is where you differentiate. You get one big swing. Maybe it's a research platform. Maybe it's sophisticated sourcing infrastructure. Maybe it's portfolio support tools. Choose based on where your fund's competitive advantage actually is.

questions.section: Phase 1: Learn What Your Fund Needs First
questions.question: How long might the learning phase take?

options.text: A few months - that's fine, building the wrong thing wastes more time

questions.explanation: This learning phase might take a few months. That's fine. Building the wrong thing wastes more time than taking time to understand what to build.

questions.question: What is the bottom line for sequencing your tech stack?

options.text: Three phases - don't skip them. Learn first, build backbone and quick wins, then decide on your big swing.

questions.explanation: Three phases. Don't skip them. Phase 1: Learn what your fund needs. Phase 2: Build the backbone (CRM, fund ops) and quick wins. Phase 3: Decide on your big swing based on where your fund's competitive advantage is. This approach avoids common mistakes and builds momentum.
